children.name: The area in which the Ubiquitous language is modeled
The UL is specific to the bounded context
The language used when talking about the context is the same as used for naming the code
Developed by collaboration between Domain Experts and developers
Without the concept of a bounded context a software project can quickly turn into a big ball of mud.
Challenge the contexts to ensure you get the correct models in each
There will be many bounded contexts in a given project.
To much in one model makes things hard.
How concepts collaborate within the domain model

Example:
Allow each backlog item to be committed to a sprint. The backlog item may be committed only if it is already scheduled for release. If it is already committed to a different sprint, it must be uncommitted first. When the commit completes, notify interested parties.
Concepts we have already identified in the domain model.
Not complete, but it can be refined e.g.
Can identify the persona if useful.
The discussion around this can be used to develop the scenario
What does a bounded context look like?
The adapter communicates with the services outside the domain
You will always have multiple bounded contexts. But you have one core domain.
A subdoman is a sub part of the whole business domain
Can also be thought about as an area of expertise.
You need to have a domain expert
Supporting subdomain  supports the core domain
Generic subdomanin e.g. Authentication - may be able to use off the shelf
Core domain is where organisation is making strategic investment in software
Core domain is for a project
Dealing with a big ball of mud
Treat logical models as a bounded contexts by naming them
Two teams work on different contexts. Have to coordinate deliveries together
Two teams share a core model. Hard to implement
Upstream and downstream relationship. Have to be coordinated
Upstream - Downstream. Downstream team has to conform to upstream
Downstream team translates upstream teams model
Well documented, defined model. Good API. Used directly
Upstream team produces well documented data exchange language
Team 2 could use Team 1 but builds there own stuff
Changes in one area breaks something else
If you have to integrate think about an anti corruption layer
How do we communicate between different contexts
Disadvantage is that it can fall over
Similar to SOAP, easier but much the same problems
Insurance example. Policy published by underwriting
Claims etc can then create a policy from this.
Aggregates are the concepts that live in the bounded context.
May also hold other entities and value objects
Protect business invariants inside Aggregate boundaries
For example you might have a product aggregate. And payment method aggregate
To large  and you get transactional failures
Reference other aggregates by identity only
Update other Aggregates using eventual consistency
Root entity represents entire aggregate concept
Design your aggregates based on UL
Over abstracting can override the UL
UI will tend to follow the abstractions
Adhere to the mental model of the domain experts
Real time updates should be in the same aggregate
Other aggregate consume and are updated
Order of the publishing can be important
You have a ProductCreated event that publishes the event
An event for everything that happens to aggregate
DDD is all about experimentation, crunching knowledge and iteration
This all takes time - a limited resource.
Estimation / no estimates not usually acceptable.
You need the right people, domain experts and developers
Need to ask the right question
You need a range of sticky notes
Modeling surface - big roll of paper. 10m long
Someone comes up with the first event.
Doesn't need to be the first event.
Build up a series of domain events in time order.
Model commands that cause domain events.
Physical match the commands with the events
Create clusters of aggregates, commands and events
Can re arrange sticky notes but don't change time based order
Optional depending on what you are doing.
Avoid task board shuffle for designing
School of thought that DDD is anti agile as you are designing up front
Modeling Debt - if you are time boxed you will want to refine your model later.
Call out modeling debt so it can be addressed.
Can use the output from the event storming as estimation units.
Compare the time taken in the estimation to the actual time.
